ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Medieval advice literature, mostly (but not exclusively) in the mirror for princes genre. Skills relating to comparative literature in general.
A wonderful survey of medieval arab and European literature - with a focus on the critical analysis, political thought, and purpose

I got the opportunity to read a lot of medieval advice literature from Europe and the Middle East, particularly in the genre of "mirrors for princes." Many of these texts are foundational in the history of political philosophy, including Machiavelli's Prince and Nizam al-Mulk's Book of Government. There is very little close reading in the class, as you might get in a course on political philosophy. Instead, it focuses principally on broader considerations about form, genre, and literary context.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strenghts:
- great and engaging instructor
- very interesting material
- good facilitation of class discussions
- instructor receptive to feedback and dissenting opinions

Weaknesses
- course could benefit from slight re-organisation to enhance analysis and reduce redundancy
- sometimes too much reading material
Dr T is a gem - a well-rounded scholar with a knack for performance, he makes the course worth it

The readings were well-selected and the instructor was charismatic and competent. The use of unstructured "thought papers" (reflections) rather than short papers to keep track of student engagement was well-suited to the format of the course. However, the course was decidedly lacking in structure. There were no student presentations or close-reading exercises in class. One brings whatever observations one has to the table, and then others will either bite or move on. There are also quite a lot of readings---the lack of close reading allows one to skim and pay more attention to formal aspects, but I thought that it did the foundational works quite a bit of injustice.

I think a lot of the strength and weaknesses of the course were discussed fruitfully in class. In terms of weaknesses having a more extensive scaffolding of historical context for our readings would have been very helpful, not only for understanding each text independently, but also for helping to piece together a narrative about how "advice literature" transformed overtime and in different cultures. Lastly, the course does require a lot of reading, which was often difficult to complete in a singe-week timespan - I liked having all the readings assigned but I think that I could have benefited from smaller selections of a text, so that I could have more time to contemplate it. 

There were other aspects of the organization of the course that were big strengths in my opinion - the weekly thought papers was a wonderful way to process the material, and I really enjoyed the mandatory outside lectures that we were required to go to. I also really appreciated our final project (a mirror) which helped me translate the kinds of learnings from our readings into real life. I cannot overstate how stimulating this exercise was!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
yes, for the reasons above. I would suggest a slight reorganisation of the course:

- 3 broad "traditions" to compare: Arabic-Islamic, Latin/Christian, Chinese
- these three traditions to be done one after the other (so students can understand cultural-specific aspects of literature in more detail)
- texts presented chronologically within these 3 blocks
- perhaps a summary session at the end
Yes! if not for the readings, the superb final project - take it for professor toorawa!
Absolutely! take it if you have any interest in either medieval literature or governance literature.

I would recommend it for the upper-level student who has an interest in being exposed to a lot of medieval literature that they otherwise would not read on their own. Reading them all in succession over one semester is helpful for bringing out certain formal and thematic affinities. 

However, I would not recommend it for someone not well-versed in the historical context of the middle ages or someone who wants a course that emphasizes close-reading. For me, having taken many close-reading-based courses, it was a good supplement.
I would definitely recommend this course, especially if the syllabus during the next iteration includes more contextualizing material!
